title: Why I'm Betting 14% Of My Portfolio On Micron (The Memory Wall Thesis)
text: Micron Technology (MU) is poised for explosive growth, driven by surging AI demand and its dominant position in high-bandwidth memory (HBM) for leading GPUs. MU's HBM products are sold out through 2025, with major customers like Nvidia and AMD, and the upcoming inference wave will further accelerate memory demand. Despite all-time highs, MU trades at deep discounts to sector multiples, with strong revenue, EBITDA growth, and margin expansion supporting a $250 price target by FY26.

title: Is It Time To Sell The Rip In Micron?
text: Micron Technology has surged by 55% since my last bullish call, driven by strong AI memory demand and raised guidance for Q4 earnings. MU consistently beats earnings estimates, and I expect another double beat with EPS potentially exceeding $2.86 and robust guidance for fiscal 2026. Despite a significant run-up, MU remains attractively valued at a forward P/E of about 11. My one-year price target is now $215.

title: Why I Am Trimming My Micron Position (Rating Downgrade)
text: Micron Technology, Inc. has delivered strong returns using a disciplined, deep cyclical investment strategy, outperforming the S&P 500 over multiple cycles. I am trimming my MU position by half, following my historical approach of selling after significant recoveries to manage risk in cyclical stocks. Despite trimming, I am holding half of MU due to AI tailwinds, potential rate cuts, inflation dynamics, and a strong cash position.

title: Micron Q4: I Sold My Entire Stake (Rating Downgrade)
text: Micron Technology, Inc.'s premium window runs through FY2026. HBM contracts and tight supply lock in margins now, but these dynamics are temporary. By 2027, new fabs and aggressive competitor output will likely flood the market, driving down pricing power and moderating revenue growth. AI keeps troughs shallower, but memory remains cyclical. Sentiment will swing, and Micron is more likely to be devalued than re-rated as a stable compounder.

title: Micron Technology: Strong Buy As HBM Chips Power The Next Wave Of AI Growth

MU posted robust Q4 results with 46% YoY sales growth, driven by DRAM and High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) strength, and expanding margins. Guidance for Q1 2026 forecasts 10% sequential revenue growth and improved gross margins, with HBM4 ramp-up expected to drive further gains.

title: 1 Spectacular Semiconductor Stock (Besides Nvidia and AMD) to Buy Hand Over Fist Before 2026
text: Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices supply some of the world's most sought-after graphics processing units (GPUs) for data centers, which are the primary chips used in artificial intelligence (AI) development. As a result, when Wall Street talks about semiconductor companies, those two names get the most attention.

title: Up 85% YTD, More Returns In Store For Micron Stock?
text: As generative AI transforms various industries, one of the most essential – yet frequently overlooked – elements driving this change is memory. Memory manufacturer Micron (NASDAQ:MU) is central to this evolution, supplying the high-bandwidth memory (HBM) and DRAM necessary to keep extensive AI models operating at both speed and scale.

title: Is Micron Stock the Best Buy Now?
text: Micron Technology (MU -3.07%) has proved to be one of the biggest winners of the global artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure buildout. While semiconductor companies like Nvidia and Broadcom often take center stage, Micron also plays a crucial role in supplying the memory and storage required for AI systems.

title: Micron: Don't Repeat The Same Mistakes Again
text: Micron Technology has surged on AI CapEx momentum and HBM leadership, but post-earnings selling suggests caution near previous highs. MU's earnings and HBM4 ramp support bullish sentiment, yet cyclicality risks and compressed free cash flow margins remain justified concerns. Sustained AI-driven demand is critical; watch for broad enterprise SaaS adoption to justify current valuations and aggressive spending.

title: Data Centers And AI Are Micron's Edge
text: Micron Technology remains a buy, with robust growth fueled by AI and data center demand and a 50% revenue increase in 4Q FY2025. MU's DRAM and HBM sales are surging, driven by tight supply, favorable pricing, and strategic partnerships with industry leaders like Nvidia and Google. The Cloud Memory Business Unit hit record revenues, now comprising 40% of total sales, highlighting MU's shift toward high-growth AI and data center markets.

title: Micron's DRAM Revenues Hit $28.6B: Can the Momentum Continue?
text: MU's DRAM sales surge 62% to $28.6B in fiscal 2025, fueled by HBM demand for AI servers and tight supply boosting margins.

title: Is Micron Technology Stock About to Break Out?
text: Micron Technology ( MU ) has been on fire in recent months, riding the wave of the AI infrastructure boom alongside leaders like Nvidia ( NVDA ) and Vertiv ( VRT ). As demand for high-performance memory and storage surges for AI applications, Micron has reemerged as one of the most compelling opportunities in the market.

title: Is Micron Cheap For A Reason?
text: Micron Technology's growth is fueled by hyperscaler data center expansion, AI-driven demand, with Cloud Memory showing the strongest sequential growth at 34%. Though a few historical factors have caused Micron's current undervaluation, its fundamentals remain strong, with industry-leading earnings growth and EBITDA margins. The company's outlook is bright, with Cloud Memory's impact on overall revenue expected to strengthen further.

title: Micron's AI Mania In Full Swing: Potential Correction Ahead
text: Micron Technology's memory demand destruction is well behind us, as the close partnership with NVDA and 6 hyperscalers drives its renewed growth opportunity. With an outsized FQ4'25 performance and promising FQ1 '26 guidance, I can understand why the consensus has drastically raised their estimates and FOMO traders have piled in. With MU also reporting demand recovery in the automotive and industrial end markets, we believe that the rally has been well deserved, albeit occurring rather fast/furiously.

title: Micron's Rally Isn't Over, But Some Investors Should Think About Leaving
text: Micron Technology, Inc. has surged over 15% post-earnings, driven by record revenue, strong AI/data center demand, and robust DRAM/HBM growth. MU's fundamentals are outstanding, with efficient operations, rising free cash flow, and leadership in advanced memory technologies for AI infrastructure. Despite its transformation, MU remains cyclical; current fundamentals suggest a mid-to-late cycle position, with potential normalization in 2026.

title: Breaking The Cycle: How AI Transforms Memory Stock Micron
text: Micron is well-positioned to benefit from surging AI datacenter memory demand, driven by high-performance HBM products and tight DRAM supply. AI model complexity, larger context windows, and the rise of AI agents are fueling unprecedented memory requirements, outpacing even GPU demand growth. MU's forward-looking CapEx, secured HBM3E contracts, and anticipated HBM4 launch position it as a performance leader in a seller's market.

title: Micron: HBM On Rocket Fuel And NAND Shortage Tailwinds
text: Micron Technology's FY25 earnings results confirmed a sharp turnaround, an event I anticipated in April this year. Revenue hit $37.4B (+49% yoy), and gross margin expanded 17 pts to 41%. DRAM remains the growth engine: tight supply lifted ASPs by low double-digits sequentially; DRAM revenue rose 69% yoy and now represents 79% of total revenue. A new pillar for my bull case is emerging: industry-wide NAND chip shortages could improve ASPs and margins, supporting triple-digit EPS growth over the next three quarters.
